para.text: In this chapter, the documents set forth in §B of this regulation are incorporated by reference.

In compliance with Business Occupations and Professions Article, §§12-101(p) and 12-205(a), Annotated Code of Maryland, the Board adopts the most recent version of the following Codes as they may be amended, modified, or updated from time to time.
The International Plumbing Code (International Code Council, 500 New Jersey Avenue, N.W., 6th Floor, Washington, DC 20001), which has been incorporated by reference in COMAR 09.12.50.02-1B(2).

The International Residential Code, (International Code Council, 500 New Jersey Avenue, N.W., 6th Floor, Washington, DC 20001), which has been incorporated by reference in COMAR 09.12.50.02-1B(4) and 09.12.51.04A(2).
The International Fuel Gas Code (International Code Council, 500 New Jersey Avenue, N.W., 6th Floor, Washington, DC 20001).
The most recent version of the National Fuel Gas Code, NFPA 54.
The Liquefied Petroleum Gas Code, NFPA 58.

para.text: In this regulation, the following terms have the meanings indicated.
Containing not more than a weighted average of 0.25 percent lead when used with respect to the wetted surface of pipes, pipe fitting, plumbing fittings, and fixtures; and
Not containing more than 0.2 percent lead when used with respect to solder and flux.
“NSF” means the standards of the National Sanitation Foundation.

The weighted average lead content of a lead-free pipe, pipe fitting, plumbing fitting, or fixture shall be calculated by using the following formula: For each wetted component, the percentage of lead in the component shall be multiplied by the ratio of the wetted surface area of that component to the total wetted surface area of the entire product to arrive at the weighted percentage of lead of the component. The weighted percentage of lead of each wetted component shall be added together, and the sum of these weighted percentages shall constitute the weighted average lead content of the product. The lead content of the material used to produce wetted components shall be used to determine compliance with lead-free requirements. For lead content of materials that are provided as a range, the maximum content of the range shall be used.

The use of platings, coatings, or acid wash treatments may not be used to meet the 0.25 percent weighted average lead content requirements set forth in Business Occupations and Professions Article, §§12-101(h-1)(4) and 12-101(q)(4) and(5), Annotated Code of Maryland.

Materials used to dispense water intended for human consumption through drinking or cooking, including piping, faucets, and valves as set forth in §§F and G of this regulation, shall be lead-free, containing not more than a weighted average of 0.25 percent lead with respect to the wetted surface as defined in §A(2)(a)(ii) of this regulation.
Solder and flux for soldered joints in potable water piping shall be lead-free, containing not more than 0.2 percent lead, as defined in §A(2)(a)(ii) of this regulation.
Flux shall be recommended by the manufacturer for making soldered joints in lead-free potable water supply system piping.
Potable water supply components that are within the scope of NSF 61 for drinking water system components and are required to be lead-free shall comply with NSF 61 and NSF 372.
Potable water system components that are not within the scope of NSF 61 for drinking water system components but are required to be lead-free shall comply with NSF 372.
Potable water system components that are not required to be 0.25% lead-free shall be suitable for distributing potable water but may contain up to 8% lead.
Potable water end-use devices and potable water supply system piping that are intended to dispense water for human consumption through drinking or cooking include, but are not limited to:
Commercial grocer or supermarket misting systems used for produce;
Production equipment for processed food containing water; and
Any other end-use device or piping that is intended to dispense or convey water for human consumption.
Piping components that shall be lead-free when used with lead-free end-use devices and piping that are required to be lead-free include, but are not limited to:
Any other piping component associated with an end-use device or water supply piping that is required to be lead-free.
Materials Not Required to Be Lead-Free.

Pipes, pipe fittings, plumbing fittings or fixtures, including backflow preventers, that are used exclusively for nonpotable services such as manufacturing, industrial processing, irrigation, outdoor watering, or any other uses where the water is not anticipated to be used for human consumption are not required to be lead-free.

Potable water end-use devices and water supply system components not anticipated to dispense or convey water to be used for human consumption and not required to be lead-free, including the associated supply piping of such devices and components, include, but are not limited to:
Shut off valves for clothes washers;
Backflow prevention devices that supply nonpotable applications;
Food production equipment that does not contact the food; and
Any other end-use device or water supply piping that is not anticipated to dispense or convey water that is to be used for human consumption.
